At-a-Glance: Wax moths exploit weak colonies and poorly stored comb. Prevention through strong colonies, tidy yards, and correct storage beats cure.
Why it Matters: Severe infestations destroy drawn comb — a major capital loss.
Larval tunnelling spreads webbing and frass, contaminating stores and equipment.
Good storage extends comb life and reduces replacement costs.
Objectives: Keep colonies strong and queenright; remove dead-outs promptly.
Store supers and brood comb in moth-resistant conditions.
Intervene early at the first sign of webbing or frass.
What Good Looks Like: Comb storage: cool, dry, light or ventilated stack with spacing to disrupt moth behaviour.
Regular inspection of stored boxes; cull worst frames; freeze sensitive comb.
Prompt cleaning of extraction spaces; no sticky kit left out.
Step-by-Step: 1) In-season prevention: maintain strong colonies; reduce unused space; remove dead-outs quickly.
2) Post-harvest storage: stack supers with airflow (e.g., alternating orientation) or in bright, well-ventilated rooms; consider BT-based controls where permitted.
3) Freezing: -18 °C for 24–48 h kills eggs/larvae; bag and thaw sealed to avoid moisture.
4) Monitoring: check stacks every 2–4 weeks for webbing, pellets, and musty odour.
5) Remediation: cull heavily damaged comb; scrape and scorch woodenware where safe; review storage conditions.
Seasonality & Climate: Warm, humid seasons accelerate moth life cycle.
Urban storage spaces (lofts/garages) can trap heat — ensure ventilation.
Data & Thresholds: Any active larval webbing in stored comb triggers immediate action.
Dead-outs left >7–10 days in warm weather sharply increase risk.
Diagnostics & Decision Tree: Symptom: Webbing in corners of stored frames -> Freeze batch -> Improve ventilation/stacking.
Symptom: Recurrent infestation -> Review colony strength and storage temperature/humidity.
Symptom: Moth in weak colony -> Consolidate boxes; treat underlying weakness (queen/varroa/nutrition).
Common Pitfalls: Sealing supers airtight in warm rooms (creates a moth incubator).
Leaving sticky comb in open spaces attracting adults.
Keeping vast areas of empty comb on weak colonies.
Tools & Techniques: Freezer access, breathable storage stacks, spacers for ventilation.
BT-based biocontrol products where legal, bright storage rooms.
Scrapers, heat/steam or scorching for woodenware.
Safety & Compliance: Follow labels for any biocontrols; avoid contamination of food areas.
Communications: Explain to helpers why ‘light and air’ storage works against moth lifecycle.
